heading: Title
text: "Thriving in the Food Industry: The Oatly Approach to Sustainable Business Strategies"

heading: Abstract
text: Food is a fucking problem for the environment, and it's only going to get worse with more people and their fancy diets. This article talks about how businesses can use sufficiency strategies to reduce demand and save resources. They looked at Oatly, a company that makes plant-based dairy alternatives, and found that it's possible to grow while still being sustainable. Basically, companies need to stop being so damn greedy and start thinking about the planet. More research is needed to figure out how to get everyone on board with this shit.

heading: Data Collection And Analysis
text: The fucking interview guide and list of interviewees can be found in fucking Appendix A and B. Seven goddamn interviews were recorded and transcribed using that fucking NVivo software. The first interview was transcribed using HappyScribe, but the rest were manually transcribed by one author because the automated shit was full of fucking errors. A coding list was made based on the research questions and checked by other authors. The sufficiency business strategies were turned into nodes in NVivo. The sustainability report was analyzed using the codebook from the interviews, and a node was changed to be more generic. Triangulation was used to make this research more reliable and valid, including different modes of interviews and content analysis. The conceptual framework was fed back to the company for their fucking views. The final strategies are in Appendix C.

heading: Results
text: This fucking text talks about some bullshit literature and practice review that apparently describes some business strategies for sufficiency. Then, they go on to mention some stupid conceptual framework that they probably pulled out of their ass. What a waste of fucking time.

heading: Literature And Practice Review
text: The fucking literature has identified nine fucking business strategies for sufficiency, including conscious sales and marketing techniques, creating new revenue models, demand reduction services, education and consumer engagement, full life-cycle sufficiency, nudging, premium pricing model, product longevity, and technology-based solutions. These strategies are not fucking mutually exclusive, and three additional strategies were identified through practice review, including offering quality local products, changing conventional consumer perception, and selling 'inconvenience' for a better price. These fucking strategies will be described next.

heading: Conscious Sales And Marketing Techniques
text: This fucking business strategy is all about giving customers what they fucking need instead of what they fucking want. They only sell shit that's necessary at the time of purchase and try to build long-term relationships with customers to get their loyalty and a good fucking reputation. They charge premium prices and don't offer any fucking sales incentives or discounts. They even try to get customers to think twice before buying shit and avoid unnecessary upgrades. Patagonia is a fucking example of this strategy, encouraging people to repair or buy second-hand clothes instead of buying new shit. In Denmark, supermarkets like REMA 1000, Coop, and Lidl are trying to reduce food waste by not offering any fucking volume discounts.

text: Education and customer engagement are the new business models that prioritize long-term relationships with customers over immediate sales. This means that companies are willing to sacrifice short-term profits to build trust and reputation with customers, resulting in higher loyalty and positive recommendations. Companies like Ben & Jerry's and Whole Foods Market are leading the way in promoting sustainable consumption behaviors through educational programs and green initiatives. It's about time these fucking companies start giving a shit about the environment and stop prioritizing their fucking profits over the planet.

text: This fucking article talks about some bullshit called "full life-cycle sufficiency" which is just a fancy way of saying that companies need to think about the environment when designing their products. Apparently, design is super important because it affects how people use and dispose of shit. So, if companies want people to be more sustainable, they need to design their products in a way that encourages that. There are some fancy strategies like 'Design with Intent' and 'Design for Sustainable Behavior' that can help with this. Basically, companies need to make shit that's cheap and reliable and doesn't fuck up the environment. Coca Cola Japan did this by making a water bottle that's lighter and easier to recycle.

text: Nudging is a bullshit tactic used by some professors to manipulate consumers into making sustainable choices without actually giving them a choice. They do this by designing the choice architecture and using tools like simplifying information, changing the physical environment, and setting default options. One example of this is the Swedish fast food chain Max Burgers, who offer carbon-neutral, vegetarian, and vegan options on their menu and display them in the store to brainwash customers into buying them. This has led to a 16% increase in sales of their bullshit low-carbon burgers. Other fast food chains like McDonalds and Burger King have also jumped on this bandwagon of manipulating customers into buying their fake-ass vegetarian and vegan options.

heading: Product Longevity
text: Designing products that last longer can encourage customers to dispose of them less frequently, resulting in less waste and resource use. Companies can achieve this by using high-quality materials and processes, making products durable, repairable, and upgradable. This strategy can be profitable if companies can charge a premium price or attract more customers due to superior performance. In the food industry, attempts have been made to reduce packaging waste through refillable packaging and incentivizing the use of reusable containers with discounts. Overall, designing for longevity can benefit both companies and customers in the long run.

text: The fucking food industry can save resources and shit by working together locally instead of relying on global economic flows. This makes it easier for farmers to sell their shit without spending a fuck ton on transaction costs and reduces environmental impact from transportation.

heading: Conceptual Framework Building On Literature And Practice Review
text: The fucking review found 12 business strategies for the food industry to be more sustainable, but they had to fucking split them up into 14 and change the names of some categories. They added shit like "Refillable packaging for consumables" and "Shortening ingredients list" to make it seem like they're doing something. They also fucking divided "nudging" into two separate strategies because apparently, they couldn't fucking decide. The strategies are grouped into three sections: avoid, reduce, and reuse, with the avoid strategies being the most fucking useless. The only good ones are "Providing refillable packaging for consumables" and "Repurposing food," but even those are fucking obvious. Overall, this study is a waste of fucking time.

heading: Empirical Results And Final Conceptual Framework
text: Oatly, a company in the food industry, has been found to implement nine out of 14 sufficiency business strategies, including creating new revenue models, offering quality local products, and designing products for sustainable consumption. The company's support for sustainability comes from its top leadership, which has helped maintain sustainability at the core of the company despite exponential growth. Oatly seeks to offer healthy products that are alternatives to dairy, and its products are designed to have a minimal environmental impact. The company also implements conscious sales and marketing techniques to encourage sustainable consumption. However, the company's focus on sustainability has led to discussions about designing packaging that enables consumers to easily empty it. Oatly's focus on developing products that last has been through technological solutions that allow the development of products with longer shelf lives. The company also encourages substitution of animal-based products to avoid the consumption of products with a large environmental footprint.

text: This fucking research looked at how the fuck sufficiency business strategies can be used in the goddamn food industry. Basically, they're saying that companies should focus on encouraging people to buy their fucking plant-based products instead of animal-based ones. Oatly seems to be doing a decent job at this, but they still need to fucking work on sustainable eating and shit. The research concludes that sufficiency strategies are fucking hard to implement and require a lot of fucking creativity and dedication. Companies need to fucking focus on one or a few sufficiency strategies to start with. Financial shit is important, but they didn't really fucking talk about it. Overall, food sustainability is a fucking challenge, but sufficiency strategies can help.
